cards.title: Kylie Jenner / Cornrows and the racial politics of hair
cards.rawTitle: Cornrows and the racial politics of hair

item.title: Kylie Jenner‚Äôs cornrows and the racial politics of hair
item.trailText: When Kim Kardashian‚Äôs younger sister posted a picture of a new hairstyle, she had little idea of the cultural minefield she was entering
item.standFirst: When Kim Kardashian‚Äôs younger sister posted a picture of a new hairstyle, she had little idea of the cultural minefield she was entering
item.body:
The Kardashian Klan are used to hairstyles that break the internet ‚Äì Kim‚Äôs platinum blonde dye job threatened to overshadow the whole of Paris fashion week in March. So, when Kylie Jenner, Kim‚Äôs younger sister, posted an Instagram selfie on Sunday featuring a new hairstyle, a noisy reaction was to be expected.

But Jenner might not have bargained for accusations of cultural appropriation. These came from 17-year-old Hunger Games actor Amandla Stenberg, who posted a comment that read: ‚ÄúWhen u appropriate black features and culture but fail to use ur position of power to help black Americans by directing attention towards ur wigs instead of police brutality or racism #whitegirlsdoitbetter‚Äù. By Jenner‚Äôs next selfie, the braids were gone.

Inspired by celebrities including FKA twigs and Zoe Kravitz, braids like Jenner‚Äôs are gaining popularity across ethnicities. They have been a festival favourite this year, with the back-from-the-forehead cornrow particularly popular. I‚Äôm white, and I had my hair braided for the Guardian earlier this year by Keash, a braiding service set up by school friends Taiba Akhuetie, 25, and Jessy Linton, 24.

Akhuetie, whose mother is Nigerian, said she liked the idea of these styles going across races and ethnicities, despite some negative comments from black people. While she is frustrated that braiding might be seen as a trend, rather than something here to stay, she says: ‚ÄúIf other people want to appropriate the style, I think that‚Äôs a good thing.‚Äù She compares white women braiding their hair to the now-commonplace fashion for black women to wear weaves to give the effect of straight, caucasian hair. ‚ÄúNow no one thinks about that,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHair is political, definitely, but I hope we get to a point when there‚Äôs no segregation.‚Äù

Stenberg, who posted a video about cultural appropriation of hairstyles on YouTube earlier this year entitled Don‚Äôt Cash Crop On My Cornrows, might have her work cut out campaigning against other non-black women having their hair braided. Kenya Hunt of ElleUK.com, who regularly writes about black beauty, praises Stenberg as a ‚Äúreally bright young voice‚Äù, but says: ‚ÄúI think when it comes to conversations about race and cultural appropriation, we need to pick our battles. We‚Äôre seeing people burn down black churches in America right now, people killing young black women and men because of the colour of their skin. Kylie Jenner‚Äôs cornrows that she wore for hours? That doesn‚Äôt strike me as the battle we need to have.‚Äù

headerImage.caption: Kylie Jenner‚Äôs controversial cornrows. Photograph: Kylie Jenner/Instagram

cards.title: Teenage Millionaire / A year in the life of Britain‚Äôs youngest lottery winner
cards.rawTitle: A year in the life of Britain‚Äôs youngest lottery winner

item.title: Teenage Millionaire: a year in the life of Britain‚Äôs youngest lottery winner
item.trailText: Young working-class woman wins a bundle on the lottery. We know how that story goes, right? Wrong, as BBC3‚Äôs new doc carefully shows
item.standFirst: Young working-class woman wins a bundle on the lottery. We know how that story goes, right? Wrong, as BBC3‚Äôs new doc carefully shows
item.body:
I think my interest in Big Brother has finally flatlined. By now, and having presented every possible variation of ‚Äúwomen with severe personality disorders‚Äù, ‚Äúrelatable fatties‚Äù and ‚Äúwacky guys in hats‚Äù, the show seems less a slick machine giving people their 15 minutes of fame and more like a compulsory internment camp that all citizens must pass through. It wasn‚Äôt always like this, but fairytales don‚Äôt exist any more, unless you count the distant chance of winning big on the scratchies and spending your days in a secondhand Lambo, doing doughnuts on the lawns of your enemies shouting ‚ÄúSUCK IT YOU DICKHEADS!‚Äù from the window for ever and ever, and Snapchatting the whole thing.

Jane Park, who won £1,000,000 at the age of 17, is one of the youngest people in the country to become a lottery millionaire. Jane chose to take full advantage of this new and unique opportunity and ticked ‚Äúyes‚Äù on all publicity. And so, after her win, a BBC Scotland crew followed her for a year, the fascinating results of which are now being shown nationwide on BBC3 In Teenage Millionaire.

The best thing about Jane, and there‚Äôs a lot to choose from, is that coming from the Niddrie estate in Edinburgh she never once lets fatuous tripe like ‚Äúmoney doesn‚Äôt buy happiness‚Äù leave her gob. Jane knows full well that money buys happiness, because Jane‚Äôs No 1 priority ‚Äì after procuring roughly 97% of Topshop‚Äôs inventory, a tiny chihuahua puppy called Princess and an immaculate, new-build house ‚Äì was sorting her loved ones out. As the year rolls by, this desire is manifested in mountains of Christmas presents and frequent holidays to Spain. Jane is the kind of girl to sort TripAdvisor reviews by their happy hour offers and ‚ÄúOAPs doing Tom Jones on karaoke‚Äù ranking. On a birthday trip to Benidorm for mama Park, Jane nonchalantly explains that she isn‚Äôt impressed by five-star resorts. ‚ÄúWatching sunsets?‚Äù she scoffs, pulling a face like a bulldog having trouble digesting lunch. Whether such behaviour is evidence of her inherent realness or someone trying to retain an important part of her identity, I‚Äôll let you judge.

Either way, I love Jane for idly sticking two fingers up at the idea of a spa break in Rhodes or other emblems of ‚Äúsophistication‚Äù being the only thing to aspire to. I love her twice as hard for depriving a certain type of viewer of the chaotic chavs-on-tour spectacle they might have been expecting by taking entirely normal holidays and considering sound financial options. The neat conclusion to undeserving wealth, in the British mind, is the newly rich spaffing their money on one too many signet rings and losing everything. There‚Äôs a bitter streak running through all of us, so it‚Äôs no surprise that the programme is heavy on people muttering things like: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mad isn‚Äôt it? Seventeen and winning a million pounds‚Äù from the sidelines. (‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fucking brilliant,‚Äù Jane replies drily.)

Personally, I‚Äôm delighted she got lucky. For a start, she suits the zero-frigs lifestyle to a tee. She takes a job as a Magaluf shot girl in order to make her million go further. But that million also gives her the freedom to observe that the job is ‚Äúshit‚Äù, and quit. Most people, I suspect, would be hard-pressed to conceptualise what a million quid truly is. Jane, though, is clever enough to know that the figure pitches unnervingly between ‚Äúflipping loads‚Äù and ‚Äúmight not last a lifetime‚Äù. In a meeting with a financial advisor which has clearly eroded Jane‚Äôs abundant natural vitality, she‚Äôs told a lot of stuff about investing her remaining money. Stocks and shares, Jane says, have been explained to her thousands of times, but she doesn‚Äôt really care to commit to the precise details to memory. She doesn‚Äôt care for someone else making her decisions, either; so when she gets bored of reading Pick Me Up in the various rooms of her brand new home, she moves back in with her mum and rents it out for a very tidy monthly sum.

I think Jane will be all right. Besides, she says: ‚ÄúIf I was to spend it all, then YOLO. I don‚Äôt care!‚Äù

Monday, 9pm, BBC3

headerImage.caption: Lottery winner and all-round good egg Jane Park. Photograph: Graeme Hunter
headerImage.cleanCaption: Lottery winner and all-round good egg Jane Park. Photograph: Graeme Hunter

cards.title: Ariana Grande / Singer will not be charged in doughnut-licking incident
cards.rawTitle: Singer will not be charged in doughnut-licking incident

item.title: Sweet relief: Ariana Grande will not be charged in doughnut-licking incident
item.trailText: Owner of doughnut shop does not intend to press charges after video revealed singer tasting pastries she did not buy, officials tell TMZ
item.standFirst: Owner of doughnut shop does not intend to press charges after video revealed singer tasting pastries she did not buy, officials tell TMZ
item.body:
Ariana Grande will not face charges for licking two doughnuts she did not purchase on 4 July.

Last week police in Lake Elsinore, California, and public health officials from Riverside County announced their plans to investigate a video published by TMZ that show s the singer and her backup dancer ‚Äúmaliciously lick‚Äù two doughnuts on display. A representative for the Riverside County Sheriff‚Äôs Department told TMZ that the owner of Wolfee Donuts, the scene of the video, does not wish to press charges.

Grande also faced a backlash for what she said in the video: ‚ÄúI hate Americans. I hate America.‚Äù She issued a statement apologizing for her actions but also claiming that she was upset by childhood obesity levels in the US at the time, and released a video two days later entitled Sorry Babes to apologize once more.

In the video, the pop singer and actor said she should have focused on apologizing in her statement, rather than ‚Äúpreaching about my issues with the food industry‚Äù. She said she was ‚Äúso disgusted‚Äù with herself and that the video was ‚Äúsuch a rude awakening‚Äù.

Public health officials from Riverside County investigated the doughnut shop and it has been given a B score.

headerImage.caption: Ariana Grande, seen last year, before the doughnut incident. Photograph: Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP
headerImage.cleanCaption: Ariana Grande, seen last year, before the doughnut incident.

cards.title: Kanye West / Why can't rock'n'roll's old guard handle him?
cards.rawTitle: Why can't rock'n'roll's old guard handle him?

item.title: Kanye West: why can't rock'n'roll's old guard handle him?
item.trailText: Rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll history is littered with egocentric mavericks whose bad behaviour was celebrated. So why do past greats expect Kanye to act respectfully?
item.standFirst: Rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll history is littered with egocentric mavericks whose bad behaviour was celebrated. So why do past greats expect Kanye to act respectfully?
item.body:
Everyone ‚Äì aside from the millions of people who buy his records, attend his live shows and devour his interviews ‚Äì hates Kanye West right now. Whether it‚Äôs members of the public starting moronic petitions, or former boyband members declaring him ‚Äúshite‚Äù, nobody can stand the man (apart from the millions of people who have made him the biggest pop star on the planet, as I pointed out earlier).

Yet there‚Äôs one group of people who seem to have reserved a special amount of ire for West, and that‚Äôs the greying old guard of rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll. Ageing white men in bands whose time has been and gone. Now those guys really hate Kanye.

‚ÄúHe can‚Äôt write, sing, or play. At all,‚Äù tweeted David Crosby last week, adding: ‚ÄúHe is an egomaniac, he is dumb as a post, he creates nothing, helps no one.‚Äù

It wasn‚Äôt the first time Crosby had attacked West. Back in March, he claimed the Yeezus mastermind was ‚Äúan idiot and a poser ‚Ä¶ has no talent at all.‚Äù This time he backed up his attack by saying West‚Äôs music seemed ‚Äúlike percussive poetry to me ... but not very good poetry. Mostly very bad poetry‚Äù, which sounds like something my mum might possibly say about him, and she hasn‚Äôt engaged meaningfully with pop music since Adam Faith made her go weak at the knees in 1959.

Crosby‚Äôs not alone. ‚ÄúKanye West. Utter shit‚Äù, tweeted former Oasis singer Liam Gallagher after the rapper ‚Äì backed by an entourage of UK grime stars ‚Äì pulled off the most astonishing performance at this year‚Äôs Brit awards. At least it was an improvement on his brother Noel‚Äôs viewpoint: ‚ÄúKanye West? I‚Äôd have knocked him out,‚Äù ran a recent NME coverline. Devoid of the guitarist‚Äôs usual comic wit, it seemed like a weirdly Neanderthal-like threat.

Elsewhere, Michael McDonald of Doobie Brothers fame opined that the multiple Grammy-award-winning artist who‚Äôs only ever released critically acclaimed albums is unable to ‚Äúput a couple of notes together either vocally or two bars of valid music playing an instrument ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know if I call it songwriting from a musician‚Äôs standpoint. Beck is obviously a consummate musician. He plays instruments, many instruments.‚Äù

So what is going on? You could argue that all this was simply a case of older generations not understanding the younger upstart. But then Glastonbury happened, Kanye declared himself ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs greatest living rock star‚Äù, and rock‚Äôs old timers revealed what it is that really irks them.

‚ÄúWho‚Äôs the biggest rock star in the world? That must be Elvis Presley,‚Äù said the Who‚Äôs Pete Townshend from the stage the following night, failing to grasp Kanye‚Äôs use of the word ‚Äúliving‚Äù.

Slipknot‚Äôs Corey Taylor was even moved to record a video message, complete with a slapped wrist, to tell Kanye that he had to ‚Äústop it‚Äù.

Could the reason creaking rock‚Äôn‚Äôrollers are getting all upset is that they see the ‚Äúownership‚Äù of rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll under threat? Ever since white guys got to rewrite rock history on their own terms (as Mos Def eloquently pointed out on his 1999 track Rock‚ÄôN‚ÄôRoll), they‚Äôve been relatively content to pass down from white guy to white guy, but don‚Äôt seem to be able to handle it when it‚Äôs suddenly claimed back by a black man.

Just look at the criticisms, which seem to attack Kanye West for the very things rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll supposedly celebrates: bad behaviour and egocentricity. Liam Gallagher can walk out of US tours, Slipknot can declare ‚Äúpeople = shit‚Äù, and countless metallers can spend a lifetime consuming drugs and groupies on the Sunset Strip. But when it comes to Kanye, suddenly everyone‚Äôs talking about ‚Äúmanners‚Äù and ‚Äúshowing respect‚Äù ‚Äì classic tropes displayed by white people when faced with the ‚Äúuppity‚Äù black person.

The irony is that Kanye‚Äôs behaviour isn‚Äôt even bad ‚Äì he‚Äôs a married man with a child who works obsessively and never seems to be out of control on drink or drugs. He‚Äôs better behaved than Justin Bieber! Sure, he likes to proclaim his own greatness a lot, but isn‚Äôt that what rock‚Äôn‚Äôrollers have been doing since the dawn of time? Wasn‚Äôt that part of the thrill of Oasis? Isn‚Äôt it the kind of thing even pondlife like Catfish and the Bottlemen get away with, week in, week out, on the pages of NME? So why is it OK for them but not for Kanye?

Notable exceptions who are happy to let Kanye join the party are scarce. Paul McCartney, who recently collaborated with him, shows the same kind of open mind that made the Beatles a unique musical proposition. Lou Reed ‚Äì who always boasted a more advanced empathy with, and understanding of, identity than his peers ‚Äì wrote a brilliant review of Yeezus. That he (mostly) admired it is almost beside the point ‚Äì the fact Reed engaged with West‚Äôs music, regarded him as a musical equal, is what elevates his opinion above all the others.

‚ÄúThe guy has a real wide palette to play,‚Äù he wrote, adding: ‚ÄúVery often, he‚Äôll have this very monotonous section going and then, suddenly ‚Äì ‚ÄúBAP! BAP! BAP! BAP!‚Äù ‚Äì he disrupts the whole thing and we‚Äôre on to something new that‚Äôs absolutely incredible. That‚Äôs architecture, that‚Äôs structure ‚Äì this guy is seriously smart. He keeps unbalancing you.‚Äù It‚Äôs a far cry from the typical ‚Äúhe just uses computers‚Äù and ‚Äúcan‚Äôt sing‚Äù jibes.

Elsewhere, though, there‚Äôs little love for Kanye, and even less reflection. Maybe self-examination of your kneejerk opinions is not very rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll. But it‚Äôs not doing the old guard any favours, and they‚Äôre not winning the war.

When Corey Taylor was asked if he enjoyed the frenzied reaction to his Kanye rant, he let his mask slip: ‚ÄúNo! God no! Here‚Äôs the thing: I‚Äôve written three books, I‚Äôve sold millions of albums, I‚Äôm in two different bands, I‚Äôm in movies and shit. And this is what it took? This is what it took?‚Äù

When it comes to rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll, it‚Äôs clearly Kanye‚Äôs world. All the other rockers are just whining in it.

headerImage.caption: He‚Äôs alive, and Elvis isn‚Äôt ‚Ä¶ Kanye West at Glastonbury 2015. Photograph: Jonathan Hordle/Rex Shutterstock
headerImage.cleanCaption: He‚Äôs alive, and Elvis isn‚Äôt ‚Ä¶ Kanye West at Glastonbury 2015.

cards.title: How Arnold Schwarzenegger came to star in low budget film Maggie
cards.rawTitle: How Arnold Schwarzenegger came to star in low budget film Maggie

item.title: How Arnold Schwarzenegger came to star in low budget film Maggie
item.trailText: British director Henry Hobson, who usually designs credits, enticed Hollywood action man with storyboard of everyman character that appealed to Arnie
item.standFirst: British director Henry Hobson, who usually designs credits, enticed Hollywood action man with storyboard of everyman character that appealed to Arnie
item.body:
He is a young British graphic designer who always wanted to work in the film industry, but even in his wildest dreams Henry Hobson never imagined making his directorial debut with his boyhood hero ‚Äì Arnold Schwarzenegger.

Maggie, a small budget, independent thriller about a viral pandemic, was an unlikely choice for Schwarzenegger. The film, which will be released in UK cinemas this month, was written by a first-time screenwriter and directed by Hobson, who has spent the last 15 years designing title and credit sequences for other people‚Äôs films. It had a budget of $1.4m (£900,000) the director said.

Yet Schwarzenegger came on board as both actor and producer after reading the script, playing against type as a protective father who fights to save his adolescent daughter when she becomes infected with a walking-dead virus. It is both a zombie thriller and a human story about the impact of illness.

Related: Maggie review ‚Äì Arnie stumbles through zombie day-care

Hobson, 34, born in Salisbury, Wiltshire, has no film connections in his family. His father is a university lecturer, his mother a radiographer. He could barely believe it as he watched the footage produced during the film‚Äôs 25-day shoot. Schwarzenegger is in almost every scene.

‚Äú[I thought] this isn‚Äôt quite normal. This is someone I‚Äôve grown up with seeing on screen ‚Ä¶ a pinch-yourself moment,‚Äù he said.

Schwarzenegger became intrigued by the script ‚Äì written by John Scott, a Nasa engineer ‚Äì after it appeared on the industry‚Äôs ‚Äúblack list‚Äù, for the best unproduced screenplays.

‚ÄúWhen I read it, I knew I had to do it,‚Äù the actor recalls in the production notes. ‚ÄúIt is more vulnerable than any role I have played, more real, more emotional. You‚Äôre used to seeing me play the ubermensch, the action hero bullets can‚Äôt seem to hit.

‚ÄúIn Maggie, I am the everyman ‚Ä¶ dealing with the most basic concerns ‚Äì protecting his family.‚Äù

After training at the Royal College of Art ‚Äì inspired by another former student, Sir Ridley Scott, who went on to become an Oscar-winning director ‚Äì Hobson designed the title, end and credit sequences for films such as Robin Hood and Sherlock Holmes.

There is a ‚Äúcommunity of ardent graphic design fans‚Äù, but audiences are generally more interested in their popcorn or in grabbing their coats when the credits roll: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll see the film, watch your work come on ‚Äì and then you see all these faces turning [away from the screen],‚Äù Hobson said.

He used his skills as a visual artist to woo Schwarzenegger, producing storyboard images that were so intricate and extensive, they spanned some 200 pages. They detailed ‚Äúmy thoughts behind each scene‚Äù, he said. ‚Äú[Schwarzenegger had] never seen that before ‚Ä¶ It put him in my headspace.‚Äù

Hobson produced similar images for the rest of his cast, including Abigail Breslin, Oscar-nominated for Little Miss Sunshine, and Joely Richardson, whose recent films include Endless Love.

Despite taking a break from movies to become California‚Äôs governor from 2003 to 2011, his popularity remains high. Having struggled to interest financiers, Maggie‚Äôs budget was found as soon as Schwarzenegger was attached to the project.

‚ÄúHe was such a dedicated actor,‚Äù said Hobson. ‚ÄúI felt I was able to get an untapped gem with Arnold. He‚Äôs such an amiable personality. He puts everyone at ease.‚Äù

The film will be released on 24 July. It premiered at the Tribeca film festival in April to mixed reviews.

Rupert Preston, managing director of Vertigo, the film‚Äôs UK distributor, said: ‚ÄúFor a first-time director on a fairly low-budget, very independent movie, to attach one of the biggest stars in the world is extraordinary.‚Äù

displayImages.altText: Schwarzenegger said he was looking forward to playing an everyman character in Maggie.

headerImage.caption: Schwarzenegger said he was looking forward to playing an everyman character, as a father trying to save his daughter, in Maggie. Photograph: Yonhap/AAP
headerImage.altText: Schwarzenegger said he was looking forward to playing an everyman character in Maggie.
headerImage.cleanCaption: Schwarzenegger said he was looking forward to playing an everyman character, as a father trying to save his daughter, in Maggie.

image.altText: Schwarzenegger said he was looking forward to playing an everyman character in Maggie.

cards.title: Fare play / Sachin Tendulkar reveals bus stop cry for help was prank
cards.rawTitle: Sachin Tendulkar reveals bus stop cry for help was prank

item.title: Fare play: Sachin Tendulkar reveals bus stop cry for help was prank
item.trailText: Revered Indian cricketer sparked bombardment of Twitter messages when he posted pictures of himself in Oxfordshire village and claimed to need a lift
item.standFirst: Revered Indian cricketer sparked bombardment of Twitter messages when he posted pictures of himself in Oxfordshire village and claimed to need a lift
item.body:
When the Indian cricket legend Sachin Tendulkar said on social media that he had missed the last bus home, from the unlikely location of a small village in Oxfordshire, his adoring fans were only to happy to help.

The former India captain posted pictures of himself on Twitter and Instagram by a bus stop on Saturday afternoon, accompanied by the words: ‚ÄúIn Great Haseley Oxfordshire. Missed the last bus, can anyone give me a lift??‚Äù

However, it has now been revealed that, like the T in the Park tent bag man, Tendulkar was playing a prank. After the fuss over the story, which was reported back in India, the little master decided to clarify things on Monday. He reposted the same pictures as on Saturday but overwritten with the words: ‚ÄúNot the bus. But some seem to have missed the joke.‚Äù

Related: Ashes 2015: Joe Root leaves Australia‚Äôs bowlers with no margin for error | Jason Gillespie

Tendulkar had been watching Andy Murray on centre court at Wimbledon on Friday. And Liz Sharp, who works at the Plough pub in Great Haseley, told the Guardian that Tendulkar had dropped in for lunch there on Saturday with four others.

‚ÄúMy partner, Steve Webster, was cooking in the kitchen,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe kind of recognised him but wasn‚Äôt sure until he saw it on social media. They were just messing around. He had a car in the car park. It was definitely a joke. It‚Äôs a really picturesque village but you don‚Äôt get many buses. You would get the odd one but you‚Äôd have to wait three or four hours.‚Äù

But his legion of fans were not going to let the joke tarnish their very high opinion of him. As Virat Parmar wrote: ‚Äúgod level sarcasm is obviously difficult to understand for humans!‚Äù

Despite being a long way from his home town of Mumbai, Tendulkar was bombarded withmessages from adoring supporters offering help after the original post on Saturday. More expressed regret that they could not assist (in the main because they were in India).

Typical was the reaction of Gobin Insan, who wrote: ‚ÄúI wish I could give u [a lift] sir god of cricket.‚Äù Amit Gosh was similarly gushing, writing: ‚Äú@sachin_rt anyone will give you a lift!! You are the #GodofCricket And how often do a mortals meet God!!‚Äù

Related: Fall in Sky Ashes viewing figures leaves English cricket facing stark choices | Sean Ingle

One tweeter @crazydreameruk even appeared to have gone to the bus stop in question, providing photographic evidence with the message: ‚ÄúI came to get you but couldn‚Äôt find you.‚Äù

There was also concern for Tendulkar. Dinakar Kamuth wrote: ‚Äú@sachin_rt what happened to your security sir? you are not protected in UK? unbelievable.No arrangement or is it that you are joking?‚Äù

Related: How England and Australia compared in the first Ashes Test at Cardiff

headerImage.caption: Sachin Tendulkar at Wimbledon, where he watched Andy Murray play. Photograph: Dominic Lipinski/PA
headerImage.cleanCaption: Sachin Tendulkar at Wimbledon, where he watched Andy Murray play.

cards.title: Ellen Degeneres / The latest celebrity to join the lifestyle site clan
cards.rawTitle: The latest celebrity to join the lifestyle site clan

item.title: Ellen Degeneres: the latest celebrity to join the lifestyle site clan
item.trailText: The comedian and talkshow host has launched a home and lifestyle website. What lessons can we learn from EDbyEllen?
item.standFirst: The comedian and talkshow host has launched a home and lifestyle website. We‚Äôre calling it Ellencore. What lessons can we learn from EDbyEllen?
item.body:
Loath as we are to mock Ellen Degeneres, news that her new lifestyle site has almost sold out of cheese knives leaves us with little choice.

Last week, the comedian, campaigner, chatshow host, Oscars host, CoverGirl spokesperson and 50th most powerful woman in the world launched her lifestyle site, EDbyEllen. Within 24 hours, 300,000 users had signed up to the site, with most of the (actually affordable) stock selling out.

The main difference between EDbyEllen and, say, Gwyneth Paltrow‚Äôs Goop or Blake Lively‚Äôs Preserve is that it focuses less on prescriptive seed advice and more on the joys of homemaking, Monopoly-inspired pig pins and baseball caps. Ellencore, if you will. Because the internet‚Äôs capacity is almost as unlimited as our need for celebrity-endorsed lifestyle advice, it‚Äôs perhaps unsurprising that she has branched out into a lifestyle site. With that in mind, here are some foolproof ways to make your life more Ellen-y.

Make people aware of your emotional state ...

Lengthy affirmations embody the EdbyEllen philosophy. However, if you don‚Äôt have time to print out, laminate and hang stuff like ‚ÄúI want people to be able to express themselves in a very stylish yet comfortable and unique way. And whether they know it or not, they‚Äôre expressing love‚Äù over your headboard, wearing this T-shirt sends a pretty direct message.

... or your loosely religious one

Simply by buying this bag.

Give your dining room a ‚Äòtouch of whimsy‚Äô

Like, four coasters emblazoned with pictures of kale. Or a napkin that can make you laugh.

Bucolic is the new black

In the spirit of Preen spring/summer 2015 ‚Äì or, apparently, Ellen spring/summer 2015 ‚Äì cricket/tennis jumpers are one of the site‚Äôs top sellers, regardless of whether a jumper is actually useful in the searing heat of LA (where Degeneres lives). See also the pig pins and goat-logo T-shirts. Very LA (not).

bodyImages.caption: Gotta have a faith tote bag. $25 Photograph: EdbyEllen
Kale coasters. What more can one say? $50 Photograph: EdbyEllen
bodyImages.cleanCaption: Kale coasters. What more can one say? $50

bodyImages.caption: A tennis jumper: ideal for Californian summers, $145 Photograph: EdbyEllen
bodyImages.cleanCaption: A tennis jumper: ideal for Californian summers, $145
